overview.description: This assessment evaluates agents' understanding of federal AI policy frameworks, executive orders, and governance structures that shape artificial intelligence implementation across government agencies. The quiz covers key executive orders, memoranda, risk management frameworks, and leadership roles that define how the United States federal government approaches AI adoption, safety, and oversight. Successful completion demonstrates comprehension of the regulatory landscape governing AI in government operations.
learningObjectives: Understand the evolution of federal AI executive orders and their requirements
Identify key AI policy frameworks and governance structures
Recognize the roles of federal agencies in AI safety and oversight
Understand AI procurement policies and their objectives
Learn about the NIST AI Risk Management Framework
Recognize the importance of the U.S. AI Safety Institute
Understand the coordination mechanisms for national AI strategy
prerequisites: Week 1: Fundamentals of AI course material
Week 2: Bias and Responsible AI Use course material
Week 3: AI Transparency and Ethics course material

questions.text: Which Executive Order first required agencies to keep public inventories of federal AI use cases?

options.label: A
options.text: Executive Order 13960 – "Promoting the Use of Trustworthy Artificial Intelligence in the Federal Government"
options.reasoning: Executive Order 13960, signed in December 2020 by President Trump, was the first to mandate that federal agencies maintain and publicly share inventories of their AI use cases. This transparency requirement established baseline visibility into how AI was being deployed across government operations and set the foundation for subsequent AI governance frameworks. The order required agencies to document their AI systems and share these inventories with both other government agencies and the public.

options.label: B
options.text: Executive Order 2025½ – "Galactic Artificial Intelligence Independence Day"

options.label: C
options.text: Executive Order 14179 – "Accelerating the Nation's Use of Artificial Intelligence"

options.label: D
options.text: Executive Order 14110 – "Safe, Secure, and Trustworthy Development and Use of Artificial Intelligence"

questions.text: What is the purpose of the "America's AI Action Plan" (July 2025)?

options.label: A
options.text: Accelerate adoption while reducing administrative burden and supporting innovation
options.reasoning: America's AI Action Plan aims to accelerate responsible AI adoption across federal agencies by reducing unnecessary administrative barriers while maintaining appropriate oversight and supporting innovation. The plan emphasizes streamlining governance processes to enable agencies to deploy AI solutions more rapidly while ensuring safety, security, and ethical standards are maintained. It represents a shift toward enabling AI deployment rather than creating additional bureaucratic hurdles.

questions.text: The Executive Order 14179 – "Accelerating the Nation's Use of Artificial Intelligence" (January 2025) primarily aimed to:

options.label: A
options.text: Remove barriers and streamline governance to speed AI use
options.reasoning: Executive Order 14179 focuses on removing bureaucratic obstacles and streamlining governance mechanisms to accelerate the responsible deployment of AI across federal agencies. Rather than adding new layers of complexity, this order seeks to make it easier for agencies to adopt AI technologies while maintaining necessary safeguards and oversight. It represents a deliberate effort to reduce friction in AI adoption processes that may have been hindering innovation.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

questions.text: The OMB Memorandum M-25-21 – "Accelerating Federal Use of Artificial Intelligence through Innovation, Governance, and Public Trust" instructs agencies to:

options.label: A
options.text: Stop publishing AI inventories

options.label: B
options.text: Designate Chief AI Officers and run risk-based governance
options.reasoning: OMB Memorandum M-25-21 directs federal agencies to establish clear AI governance structures, including the designation of Chief AI Officers who are responsible for implementing risk-based governance frameworks. This approach ensures that AI deployment is managed strategically with appropriate oversight while building public trust through transparent and accountable practices. Chief AI Officers serve as the central point of authority and accountability for AI initiatives within their agencies.

options.label: C
options.text: Use only U.S.-built large language models

options.label: D
options.text: Replace all Chief Data Officers with Chief AI Officers

questions.text: The OMB Memorandum M-25-22 – "Driving Efficient Acquisition of Artificial Intelligence in Government" focuses on:

options.label: A
options.text: State and local AI funding

options.label: B
options.text: Defining export controls

options.label: C
options.text: Efficient AI acquisition (competition, data/model rights, portability, lifecycle oversight)
options.reasoning: OMB Memorandum M-25-22 provides guidance on procuring AI systems efficiently and effectively. It emphasizes promoting competition among vendors to ensure the government gets the best value, ensuring appropriate data and model rights are retained by the government to avoid vendor lock-in, maintaining system portability so agencies can switch providers if needed, and establishing lifecycle oversight to manage AI systems from acquisition through retirement. These principles help agencies make smart procurement decisions.

options.label: D
options.text: Closing AI programs

questions.text: What is the goal of federal AI procurement policy overall?

options.label: A
options.text: Encourage responsible innovation while maintaining transparency, fair competition, and oversight
options.reasoning: Federal AI procurement policy seeks to balance innovation with accountability. The overarching goal is to enable agencies to adopt cutting-edge AI capabilities while ensuring transparency in how systems are acquired and used, maintaining fair and open competition in the marketplace to prevent monopolies and ensure taxpayer value, and providing appropriate oversight to protect public interests and maintain ethical standards. This balanced approach supports both technological advancement and responsible governance.

options.label: B
options.text: Delay new AI projects until 2030

options.label: C
options.text: Limit AI purchases to domestic hardware only

options.label: D
options.text: Require every contract to include a chatbot

questions.text: Which framework is the government's go-to reference for managing AI risk?

options.label: A
options.text: Another chatbot platform above

options.label: C
options.text: FIPS 199

options.label: D
options.text: NIST AI Risk Management Framework (AI RMF)
options.reasoning: The NIST AI Risk Management Framework (AI RMF) is the federal government's primary reference for identifying, assessing, and managing risks associated with AI systems. Released by the National Institute of Standards and Technology in January 2023, this voluntary framework provides a structured approach to managing AI risks throughout the system lifecycle and has been widely adopted across federal agencies. It provides guidance on trustworthy AI characteristics including being valid and reliable, safe, secure and resilient, accountable and transparent, explainable and interpretable, privacy-enhanced, and fair with harmful biases managed.

options.label: E
options.text: FedRAMP

questions.text: Which institute leads AI safety testing and guidance for the U.S. government?

options.label: A
options.text: The U.S. AI Safety Institute at NIST
options.reasoning: The U.S. AI Safety Institute (US AISI), established within NIST in 2024 following Executive Order 14110, serves as the federal government's lead organization for AI safety research, testing, and guidance. This institute develops standards, conducts safety evaluations of advanced AI models, provides authoritative guidance to help agencies deploy AI systems safely and securely, and coordinates with international AI safety institutes. It houses the AI Safety Institute Consortium (AISIC) with over 290 member organizations from industry, academia, and civil society.

options.label: B
options.text: U.S. Digital Service

options.label: C
options.text: DHS Office of the Inspector General

options.label: D
options.text: FCC

questions.text: Which group of entities helps coordinate national AI strategy and advice across agencies?

options.label: A
options.text: NSF

options.label: B
options.text: OSTP + National AI Initiative Office (NAIIO) + National AI Advisory Committee (NAIAC)
options.reasoning: National AI coordination is managed through a collaborative structure involving the Office of Science and Technology Policy (OSTP), the National AI Initiative Office (NAIIO), and the National AI Advisory Committee (NAIAC). OSTP provides White House-level science and technology policy leadership and coordination. NAIIO coordinates federal AI research and development activities across agencies. NAIAC provides independent advice and recommendations on AI policy, research priorities, and workforce issues. Together, these entities work to coordinate AI strategy, research priorities, and policy recommendations across the federal government.

options.label: C
options.text: Only the DoD CIO

options.label: D
options.text: Department of Commerce

questions.text: Which statement best describes key AI leadership roles in the federal government?

options.label: A
options.text: Each agency designates a Chief AI Officer; OSTP provides White House science/tech leadership; NIST via the AI Safety Institute leads AI safety work
options.reasoning: Federal AI leadership operates through a distributed model where each agency designates its own Chief AI Officer to manage agency-specific AI initiatives and ensure responsible implementation. At the executive level, the Office of Science and Technology Policy (OSTP) provides strategic direction and policy coordination from the White House, setting government-wide AI priorities. NIST, through its U.S. AI Safety Institute, provides technical leadership on AI safety standards, testing methodologies, and evaluation frameworks. This structure balances agency autonomy with centralized coordination and safety oversight.

options.label: B
options.text: There is a single national Chief AI Officer over all agencies

options.label: C
options.text: State governors set federal AI policy

options.label: D
options.text: Only contractors lead AI policy
